On Tuesday 08 March 2005 01:22, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> Michael Schuerig wrote:
> >  > > interface CBH {
> >  > >     void onThis(String s);
> >  > >     void onThat(String s);
> >  > >     String getSomething();
> >  > > }
> >  >
> >  > That interface is too big.
> >
> > Is it? Please suggest ways to improve it.
>
> Well, getSomething() seems not to have anything to do with the event
> handler methods, so I'd move that to a different class. Maybe I need
> to see it used in context, but I even have to wonder why you'd need
> one of these things to give you a String so you could give it back
> Strings later. Why does it not just remember the String it has?

I need to provide more context...
A CallBackHandler (CBH) instance with different state is passed to each 
call of a RowHandler#handleRow method; one call for each row in a 
tabular data structure. Actual, that class is (currently) called 
RowContext and has methods such as startElement(String name), 
endElement(String name), element(String name, String contentName), and 
the incriminated getColumn(String columnName).

The use of all this is to convert flat tabular data to hierarchical XML. 
The getColumn() method is needed simply so that the RowHandler can 
determine, based on the current and previous rows, whether to start or 
end an XML (hierarchical) element.

Yes, I think, I could differentiate the single callback interface into 
two, one for parsing, the other for generating output. It seems cleaner 
and easier to test, but I fear that it's much more onerous to actually 
use. Well, I need to have a go at it to be sure.

Michael
